comments.author: mklement0
comments.body:
To _generalize_ your requirement: you want an on-demand method for invoking a given command _with elevation_, similar to what `sudo` does in the Unix world.

That would indeed be helpful, and is already being discussed in #3232.

Unless this anticipated _generic_ mechanism still wouldn't meet your needs, I suggest you close this issue.

comments.author: mklement0
comments.body:
I just realized that far more cmdlets than I was aware of in fact do have a `-Credential` parameter:

```powershell
$VerbosePreference = 'Continue'
Get-Command -type cmdlet | ? { $c = $_; try { $_.Parameters.ContainsKey('Credential') } catch { write-verbose "Failed with: $c" } }
```

Still:

* It's not readily obvious to me which cmdlets were given this parameter vs. which were not.

*  It seems to me that solving this problem at the level of _individual cmdlets_ is the wrong approach.

That said, I'll leave it to someone more knowledgeable to take it from here.

comments.author: iSazonov
comments.body:
The Get-Acl cmdlet uses reflection to invoke a method to get acl
```c#
PSMethodInfo methodInfo = _inputObject.Methods["GetSecurityDescriptor"];
```

So you should previously create the input object with elevated permissions.

comments.author: dogfish182
comments.body:
I solved my issue which was quite specific. 
I found that to invoke a command while running as system on a windows system, you need to enable credssp and enable the server component of Credssp aswell as the client portion so the system can pass credentials to itself. Then you can invoke command with a service Account that has AD access. 

```
# enable the box to accept credentials 
Enable-WSManCredSSP -role server
# enable the box to trust itself 
Enable-WSManCredSSP -Role "Client" -DelegateComputer "$env:computername.$env:userdnsdomain"
```
you can also force the command so it's possible in a script. 
Credssp has some security implications and warnings about security, so for my scope since i'm running a system via SSM and I trust myself, I enable credssp at the start, do my work and disable again at the end. Hope this helps someone one day, it cost me 2 days of confusion.

comments.author: allasto
comments.body:
Yes.
add the following before the script to enable credssp:
      Enable-WSManCredSSP -role server -force
      Enable-WSManCredSSP -Role "Client" -DelegateComputer "$env:computername.domain.com" -force

      New-Item -Path HKLM:\SOFTWARE\Policies\Microsoft\Windows\CredentialsDelegation -Name AllowFreshCredentialsWhenNTLMOnly -Force
      New-ItemProperty -Path HKLM:\SOFTWARE\Policies\Microsoft\Windows\CredentialsDelegation\AllowFreshCredentialsWhenNTLMOnly -Name 1 -Value "wsman/$env:computername.domain.com" -PropertyType String


and add this at the end to the invoke command:  -Authentication Credssp

Like:
Invoke-Command -Computer localhost -ScriptBlock $Script -Credential $Cred -Authentication Credssp
